transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Hello! Thank you for having me. I'm happy to share my experiences and insights. Please go ahead with your questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Sure! As I mentioned, my name is Isabella, and I'm 48 years old. I live in urban Chicago with my husband. I work as a real estate agent, but my job is part-time right now due to some personal circumstances. I have a high school diploma and have been focused on my family and my career for most of my life. I'm also a mother of three, and I had all my children through cesarean deliveries. I manage my type 2 diabetes fairly well, and I try to stay active, although I don't exercise as much as I should. Overall, I'm just trying to balance work and family while staying healthy. How about you?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Of course! I first learned I was pregnant with my oldest child when I was in my early twenties. I was surprised but excited at the same time. Each of my pregnancies followed that; I had my second child a couple of years later and then my youngest a few years after that. All three of my pregnancies were pretty straightforward, but I ended up having to have cesarean sections for each delivery. It was definitely a bit of a journey, and while I was nervous about the surgeries, I was just relieved to have healthy babies. 

Do you want to know more about any specific aspect of my pregnancies or experiences with prenatal care?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I sought prenatal care pretty early on in each of my pregnancies, usually around the 8 to 10-week mark. I remember feeling a mix of excitement and anxiety during those early visits. The first appointment was always a bit overwhelming because there’s so much information to take in—ultrasounds, blood tests, and discussions about nutrition and what to expect. 

I had a regular OB-GYN who I really liked, and she made me feel comfortable. She was thorough and always took the time to answer my questions, which I appreciated. The prenatal care visits became a routine for me, and even though I was nervous about the cesarean sections, I felt reassured by the support from my doctor and the healthcare team.

How about you? Is there anything specific you’d like to know about my experiences during those visits?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my prenatal care was provided by an OB-GYN that I really liked. She had a warm and friendly demeanor, which helped ease my nerves during those early appointments. I felt like I could trust her completely. She always took the time to explain everything to me in detail, which was important since I wanted to make informed decisions regarding my health and my babies' health.

I appreciated that she encouraged me to ask questions and express any concerns I had. It felt like a partnership, and I really valued that relationship. I remember feeling comfortable enough to share my worries about the cesarean sections and my diabetes management during pregnancy. She was always supportive and provided guidance tailored to my specific needs.

I think that relationship made a huge difference in my overall experience with prenatal care. I felt like I was in good hands. Do you want to know more about how I managed my diabetes during pregnancy or any other specific experiences?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I typically had prenatal appointments every four weeks during the first trimester, then every two weeks as I got closer to my due date. Toward the end, especially after I was around 36 weeks, I started seeing my OB-GYN weekly.

A typical visit usually started with checking my weight and blood pressure. Since I have type 2 diabetes, they would also monitor my blood sugar levels closely. After that, I would have a discussion with my doctor about how I was feeling and any concerns I had. She would always ask about my diet and exercise, which I found really helpful, especially in managing my diabetes.

Then came the fun part—usually, we would do an ultrasound to check on the baby's development. I loved seeing those first images! After the ultrasound, we would talk about the results, and she would explain everything in detail. If there were any tests to be done, like blood work or screenings, she would go over those with me as well.

The visits would often end with her asking if I had any questions or concerns, which I appreciated. It felt like she really cared about my experience and well-being. Do you have any specific questions about the tests or monitoring I went through during my appointments?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was fortunate that I didn't experience any major health complications aside from the typical challenges that come with managing type 2 diabetes. My blood sugar levels were well-controlled, which was a relief, but I did have to be extra vigilant about my diet and monitor my blood sugar more frequently as my pregnancies progressed.

However, I did face some issues related to chronic sinusitis, which sometimes flared up during my pregnancies. It was uncomfortable, especially with the hormonal changes, but my OB-GYN was always there to help me manage it. She recommended safe remedies and treatments that wouldn’t affect the babies. 

The biggest concern was always around the cesarean deliveries, but my doctor assured me that they were necessary for my safety and the babies' well-being. While I was nervous about the surgeries, I felt supported by my healthcare team throughout the process.

Overall, I was grateful that my pregnancies went relatively smoothly. Is there any specific aspect of my health concerns during pregnancy that you're interested in discussing further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I'm currently taking a few medications to manage my health. Since I have type 2 diabetes, I take metformin to help control my blood sugar levels. I find it pretty effective, and it helps keep my levels in check. 

Additionally, I take a daily multivitamin to ensure I'm getting the necessary nutrients, especially since I’ve had three pregnancies and want to maintain my health. I also use hormonal contraception to prevent any further pregnancies, as I have three wonderful children already and am not planning to have more.

Occasionally, I take over-the-counter medications for my chronic sinusitis when I experience flare-ups, but I always check with my doctor first to ensure they are safe to use. 

Do you have any questions about how these medications or supplements affect my health or my experiences during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I was very mindful of my diet and nutrition, especially because of my type 2 diabetes. I knew that maintaining stable blood sugar levels was crucial for both my health and the health of my babies. I focused on eating a balanced diet that included plenty of whole grains, lean proteins, fruits, and vegetables. 

I tried to limit my intake of sugary foods and refined carbohydrates, which was a bit of a challenge at times, especially with cravings. I also made it a point to monitor my carbohydrate intake to keep my blood sugar stable. My OB-GYN worked with me to develop a meal plan that suited my needs, and I would often consult with a dietitian as well, which was very beneficial.

I made sure to eat smaller, more frequent meals throughout the day to help manage my blood sugar levels. Snacks like nuts, yogurt, or cheese sticks became staples for me, as they provided sustained energy without causing spikes in my blood sugar.

Additionally, I found it helpful to stay hydrated and drink plenty of water. I also tried to incorporate some physical activity, like walking, whenever I could. It was a balancing act, but I felt good knowing that I was doing my best to nourish my body and my babies.

Is there anything specific you’d like to know about how I managed my diet or any challenges I faced during that time?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my emotions were a bit of a rollercoaster, which I think is pretty common for many women. I experienced a mix of excitement and joy as well as anxiety and stress. I was thrilled to be bringing new life into the world, but at the same time, managing my type 2 diabetes and the implications of my cesarean deliveries weighed on my mind.

I often felt a lot of pressure to ensure that I was doing everything right for my babies' health. There were moments when I worried about my blood sugar levels and how they might affect the pregnancies. Hormonal changes also contributed to mood swings, which could be challenging at times. I remember feeling a bit overwhelmed with all the changes happening in my body and life.

Having supportive family and friends made a big difference. They were always there to listen and encourage me. My husband was particularly understanding, and that helped me navigate the emotional ups and downs. I also found it beneficial to talk openly with my OB-GYN about my feelings; she reassured me and helped me find strategies to cope with the stress.

Overall, while there were challenging moments, I tried to focus on the positives and the joy of becoming a mother. Do you want to discuss how I managed any specific emotional challenges or any support systems I utilized during my pregnancies?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I had a solid support network that made a significant difference in my experience. My husband was my primary source of support. He was always there for me, whether it was attending doctor’s appointments or helping around the house. Just having him by my side helped ease my anxiety and made me feel more confident.

I also leaned on my family, especially my mother, who had experience with pregnancies and childbirth. She offered advice and encouragement, and I appreciated her willingness to help out with the kids whenever I needed a break. My friends were supportive as well; some of them had been through pregnancies themselves, so they understood what I was experiencing emotionally and physically. We shared tips, experiences, and even some laughs, which helped lighten the mood during stressful times.

Additionally, I stayed in touch with my healthcare team, and I felt comfortable reaching out to my OB-GYN whenever I had questions or concerns. Knowing I had that professional support was reassuring, especially when I was navigating my diabetes management.

Overall, having a mix of emotional support from my husband, family, and friends, along with professional guidance, helped me feel more secure during my pregnancies. Is there a particular aspect of my support network you'd like to explore further, or do you have any questions about how I managed to balance everything?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I definitely thought about my birth plan, particularly because I knew I would be having cesarean deliveries. My OB-GYN and I discussed the necessity of C-sections due to my previous deliveries and my health conditions, so I understood that it was the best option for my safety and my babies' well-being.

While I didn’t have the traditional birth plan that many might envision, I did have preferences for my delivery experience. I wanted to ensure that I had a supportive environment in the operating room, and I requested that my husband be there with me during the delivery. It was important for me to have that familiar face to help ease my nerves.

I also expressed my desire for skin-to-skin contact with the baby as soon as possible after delivery, as I had read about the benefits of bonding and breastfeeding right after birth. I wanted to be actively involved in the initial moments with my newborn, even though the delivery method was different from a vaginal birth.

Additionally, I communicated with my healthcare team about my concerns regarding pain management and recovery, given my history of cesarean sections. I wanted to ensure that I would have adequate support and resources available to help with my recovery so that I could focus on my new baby and my other children.

Overall, while my birth plan was more about preferences and ensuring a supportive atmosphere rather than a standard approach, I felt good knowing I had open communication with my healthcare provider. Is there anything specific you’d like to know about my birth preferences or how I prepared for the deliveries?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I relied on a variety of sources to learn about pregnancy and childbirth. First and foremost, I found my OB-GYN to be an invaluable resource. She provided me with a lot of information during our appointments, and I always felt comfortable asking her questions. She recommended books and articles that were evidence-based and relevant to my situation, especially since I had type 2 diabetes.

I also read several pregnancy books that covered topics like prenatal care, labor and delivery, and postpartum recovery. One book that I found particularly helpful was about managing diabetes during pregnancy, which gave me insights into how to best take care of myself and my babies.

In addition to books, I used reputable websites and online forums to gather information. I found websites from organizations like the American Diabetes Association and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists to be very informative. They had sections dedicated to pregnant women with diabetes, which addressed my specific concerns.

I also participated in a few local parenting classes that covered childbirth and breastfeeding. These classes were great for connecting with other expectant mothers and sharing experiences. They also provided practical tips that I found useful. 

Lastly, talking to friends and family who had gone through pregnancies was another way I gathered information. They shared their experiences and offered advice, which helped me feel more prepared and less alone in my journey.

Is there a particular source of information or topic that you're interested in discussing further?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby can be quite a challenge, and I approached it with careful planning. Since I have private health insurance, I was fortunate that many of my prenatal care visits, ultrasounds, and necessary tests were covered. However, I still had to consider out-of-pocket expenses, especially since I had three pregnancies close together.

To prepare for the financial side of things, I created a budget that included all the expected costs associated with having a baby. This included not just medical expenses but also baby supplies like diapers, clothing, and nursery items. I made a list of essential items and prioritized them, focusing on what we truly needed versus what might be considered luxuries.

I also looked for ways to save money. For example, I took advantage of baby showers, where friends and family generously gifted us with essentials. I also didn’t hesitate to accept hand-me-downs from friends who had children, which helped reduce costs significantly. 

Since my husband and I both work, we discussed our financial situation and made a plan to set aside some savings specifically for baby-related expenses. We also ensured that we had a financial cushion in case of unexpected expenses, like medical emergencies or additional healthcare needs.

I found it helpful to keep an open line of communication with my healthcare provider regarding costs as well. They were able to provide estimates for various services, which helped me plan better.

Overall, while it required some effort and organization, having a clear plan and support from my husband and family made it more manageable. Are there any specific financial concerns or strategies you’d like to know more about regarding my experience?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, my employment situation was definitely impacted. As I mentioned earlier, I work as a real estate agent, but I transitioned to part-time work during my pregnancies. The nature of real estate can be quite demanding, and I wanted to ensure that I was prioritizing my health and the health of my babies.

In the early stages of my pregnancies, I was able to manage my work schedule fairly well. However, as I got closer to my due dates, I found it increasingly challenging to balance work and the physical demands of pregnancy. I experienced fatigue and some discomfort, which made it harder to keep up with showings and client meetings. I decided it was best for me to reduce my workload and focus more on my health and prenatal care.

I communicated openly with my clients about my situation, which they were generally understanding about. I made sure to refer them to trusted colleagues when I needed to take time off. My husband was really supportive during this time, helping with the kids and encouraging me to take it easy.

After each delivery, I took some time off to recover and bond with my newborn, which was important to me. I was fortunate to have some flexibility in my job, allowing me to ease back into work when I felt ready. 

Overall, while my pregnancies required adjustments to my work life, I felt it was necessary for my health and well-being. Do you have any specific questions about how I navigated my work situation during my pregnancies, or would you like to know more about the support I received from my employer?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my pregnancies, I definitely thought about the postpartum period and what it would entail. I knew it was going to be a significant adjustment, especially with three children to care for. My primary plan was to focus on recovery while also being there for my newborn and my other kids.

I made arrangements for some help during the initial weeks after delivery. I spoke with my mother, and she generously offered to stay with us for a little while to assist with household tasks and help care for the children. Knowing I had that support made me feel more at ease about the transition.

I also planned to prioritize self-care during the postpartum period. I knew it was essential to take time to rest and recover from the cesarean delivery. I wanted to ensure I was emotionally and physically ready to care for my newborn and my other children, so I intended to take things slowly and not overcommit myself right away.

I was also aware of the importance of monitoring my mental health during this time. I had read about postpartum depression and anxiety, so I made a point to keep communication open with my husband and my healthcare provider. If I began to feel overwhelmed or had persistent feelings of sadness, I wanted to reach out for help right away.

In terms of breastfeeding, I planned to give it a try, as I had read about the benefits it offers both for the baby and for bonding. I spoke with my OB-GYN about resources and support groups that could assist me during this process, especially since I had some concerns about managing breastfeeding alongside my diabetes.

Overall, my plan was to create a supportive environment for myself and my family, focusing on recovery, emotional well-being, and bonding with my new baby. Is there any specific aspect of the postpartum period you’d like to discuss further, or do you have any questions about my plans and preparations?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
